DOC.HEAD: Leaders Meet Assembly
Eds: SUBS graf 10: ``At the,'' and graf 12: ``The two,'' to CORRECT Tuesday to Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: Steven Komarow is a member of the Pentagon press pool covering military operations in Panama.

Panama's newly installed leaders met with members of the last legislative assembly and other public figures under heavy U.S. guard Thursday, trying to gain control of the country and declaring a dusk-to-dawn curfew. Gunshots echoed in the streets outside as President Guillermo Endara and Vice Presidents Ricardo Arias Calderon and Guillermo Ford presided over the meeting, which contained the incongruous spectacle of U.S. soldiers in jeans, sweatshirts and other civilian clothes sprinkled throughout it. In his speech to an audience of about 200, Endara held out an olive branch to followers of deposed dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Endara, his vice presidents and members of the audience sang with special feeling their national anthem and one line in it, ``We have finally achieved our victory.'' Endara ordered a 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew in hopes of maintaining law and order as thousands of looters roamed the streets smashing in windows and hauling away goods from virtually every shop in the city. U.S. troops were too busy with snipers and small bands of armed Noriega loyalists to challenge the looters. The new government, by the accounts of most foreign observers, overwhelmingly won an election on May 7, but Noriega cancelled it and continued his rule. At the time, Endara and Ford were beaten by members of one of Noriega's ``Dignity Battalions,'' units who are still wrecking havoc in the aftermath of the U.S. military takeover that started early Wednesday morning. Two close aides to Endara, jailed by Noriega over a month ago and feared by opposition members to have been tortured or killed, appeared suddenly at the podium at the start of the session and were embraced by Endara and his two vice presidents to a warm ovation. The two men, Miguel Batista and Ivan Mojica, were spirited away by Noriega's police and had not been heard from since. They were freed from a jail by U.S. troops on Wednesday. Several people attending the session said they were grateful for the U.S. intervention. ``The United States is responsible for delivering the dream we have had since 1968,'' said cattleman Felix Espansona, an assembly member in 1952-1956. ``We have had a dictatorship for 20 years and now we feel liberated.'' Endara called the new leadership ``The National Reconstruction Government.'' In a brief speech he made no threats of retaliation against followers of Noriega, now the subject of a nationwide manhunt by the U.S. military and with a $1 million reward offered by the White House for his capture. In a bid for unity, Endara said he would welcome back members of Noriega's defense forces ``who can show they support our democracy.'' Vice President Ford said it will take some time to restore order, but U.S. troops should leave ``the sooner the better'' . He also said, ``It is highly important for our country that General Noriega be caught and be brought to justice.'' A top U.S. military official agreed that Noriega's capture is critical in restoring law and order. ``It's a problem because as long as you have the head of the snake and you have parts of the snake's body, and he can make the tapes like he did yesterday'' then you'll `have some number of hard-core loyalists,'' said Lt. Col. Bill Bennett, chief of contingency operations plans in U.S. Southern Command. The Endara government, strongly backed by President Bush, met amid tight security provided by dozens of U.S. troops who were all dressed in civilian clothes. Panamanian politicians did not want to give the impression of total dependence on U.S. supports, so the soldiers were asked not to wear their uniforms, several of them told reporters. Looking out of place with their crewcuts and bluejeans, they sat in the audience to prevent trouble in the National Assembly building. While the speeches were being delivered inside the government building, shots rang out across the street, scattering scores of looters and curiosity seekers from outside the wrought-iron gates around the Assembly. A U.S. officer in charge of security dismissed it as a minor incident. ``Only some shopkeeper firing shots into the air to scare away a looter,'' the officer told a reporter. Government officials said all public offices and buildings would be closed for the next two days _ virtually everything in Panama has been closed since the U.S. attack _ and it was unclear when they might reopen. The major exception was the Panama Canal, which resumed full operations at dawn Thursday, military officials said. Dozens of cargo ships were offshore awaiting a chance to go through the canal. The opposition to the American military takeover in the capital city was mostly disorganized, said Bennett, but some Noriega military units remained in the countryside and would have to be dealt with. With the operation more than 30 hours old, the U.S. completed taking control of the national assembly building, demolished Noriega's former headquarters and took control of other key points in the city. Late Wednesday, soldiers from the 82nd Airborne Division swept through the downtown Marriott hotel where some Americans were trapped. Bennett estimated that some 3,000 of the 24,000 U.S. troops involved in the operations were military police, who would be taking over police duties formerly carried out by Noriega's forces. ``Their mission will be to re-establish law and order in Panama City,'' he said. One of the primary duties will be to identify and hand over duties to Panamanian police officers who ``will be loyal to a democratic government,'' he said. As the police units take over downtown, attack units would turn their attention to routing out the remaining Noriega loyalists elsewhere _ a job which would be made easier if Noriega is found and captured. ``Without Noriega as a rallying point, a lot of the units out there that have been sitting on the fence will be calling to tell us that they will support the democratic government,'' he said. U.S. officers reported that there was a mortar fired overnight near Fort Clayton, a major U.S. military installation, but had no details of any damage. They also reported that a special unit seized a 65-foot Panamanian boat near the Bridge of the Americas spanning the Panama Canal. They captured 18 armed men aboard but found no explosives.
